title: New Portfolio
description: A new portfolio made from scratch with TypeScript and Webpack. The code is 100%
and leverages OOP to maximize modularity & readability. Certain pages use an encryption library
to hide information until the author's personal e-mail is supplied as a password.

title: CMYK Engine
description: This project has a 4 year long storied history that began when I resolved to make a game with my own engine,
entirely from scratch. After many missteps and restarts, the final iteration of the engine is largely complete.
The high-level functionality is done in Java, and the render, input, collision & sound pipelines are handled
efficiently in C with Vulkan and SDL2. A slow fallback pipeline using AWT is also implemented. Fonts use the
YAFF format, for which a custom fast parser was implemented.

title: Blot & Warp3D
description: A reference implementation of a creative 3D textured plane renderer I brainstormed in a graphing calculator
for both Rust and Kotlin. The Rust implementation uses gradient descent, while the Kotlin implementation
calculates U values with a single large computed expression.

title: Demonic Publisher
description: Near the end of my employment at DemonicPvP, I created a build tool with TypeScript & Electron to manage the
Kotlin & Java codebase. This gave an effortless abstraction for Maven & Gradle while standardizing the build
environment no matter what the current platform & installed JDKs are. An option was included to authenticate
with the admin panel to automatically deploy built artifacts to the development server all in 1 click.

title: Reddit Reader
description: In 2022, a popular and lucrative form of video entertainment were images of popular Reddit posts read out in a
text-to-speech voice over a generic looping background. This NodeJS project was created to prove that it is
possible to automate this content. The posts and comments shown in the final video are not screenshots from
the site, it is a scratch reconstruction of the site's UI filled in with data from the API. This was never
published since it could promote content theft.

title: XClaim
description: A somewhat popular plug-in for Minecraft game servers that allow administrators and players alike to control
modification by others in certain chunks of the game world. It boasts over 20 criteria to control, multiple
language support (thanks to a few translators), and seamless integration with popular plugins like DynMap and
BlueMap that display a top-down view of the world over HTTP. It is no longer being actively worked on.

title: XPlug & XGame
description: XPlug was an ambitious project designed to make Minecraft programming more accessible by providing an API
bridge between Java and Lua, loved for its simplicity and hot swap capabilities. By the time XPlug was
discontinued, it was possible to make very fun effects in just a few lines, such as giving every player a
glowing halo in 26 lines. XGame was developed in tandem with XPlug and allowed coding containerized mini-games for
people to enjoy. A favorite was King of the Hill, which featured a rocket launcher and a scoreboard in just
370 lines.

title: Old Portfolio
description: For most of 2022, my old portfolio could be found at
. The page was presented in the style of a terminal, offering a list of commands that the visitor could
enter to view various demos and navigate to pages within the site. The home page featured an implementation of
Tetris, and 2 fully functional online multiplayer games (Codenames and Auction Tic-Tac-Toe) could also be found.

title: Twitter Pong
description: A very simple Twitter bot that allows followers to play Pong between 2 accounts. The move to make is decided
democratically every 30 minutes. It was discontinued due to unreliable hosting and a lack of interest.

title: Reverse Minesweeper
description: An ugly cross-platform application made with Python & PyGame to answer the simple question; what would
Minesweeper be like if the numbers indicated empty spaces rather than mines? The verdict is in;
essentially nothing changes.

title: GMod Addons
description: Making funny things happen in my favorite game, Garry's Mod, is how I got my start as a programmer on
September 6th, 2015. By 2017 or 2018 I felt that I deeply understood the API. It started with flying green
chairs, then a weapon that turns people to stone, and eventually I touched 122,000+ hearts by allowing players
to kick things.
